blocks.name: Headings
blocks.description: The default heading styling across all uSwitch pages. We allow extending the sizes of these headings with %heading-{$i} so that we don't repeat similar font sizes across the site

blocks.name: Paragraphs
blocks.description: Default paragraph styling with a margin bottom.

state.name: .us-standfirst
state.description: Used for heros and introductory paragraphs

blocks.name: Lists
blocks.description: Normal list styling

blocks.name: Blockquote
blocks.description: Default blockquote

blocks.name: Primary palette
blocks.description: Our 4 base primary colours

blocks.name: Anchor
blocks.description: Anchor is a naive implementation of Tether by HubSpot. It creates an independent dropdown that is "anchored" to the bottom of the target element. We've decided to only support IE9+, as the uses of Anchor throughout uSwitch are for progressive enhancement.

markup.example:
Click me!

Kielbasa tenderloin spare ribs, andouille doner brisket chuck drumstick bresaola short loin pork t-bone ground round jowl. Ball tip pork loin doner tongue filet mignon biltong hamburger leberkas. Filet mignon kielbasa kevin short ribs, drumstick chuck shankle spare ribs tri-tip.

blocks.name: Overlay
blocks.description: .us-overlay can slide from either side and turn into a modal if .us-overlay--modal is added. To initialise call var overlay = new Overlay({options})

state.name: .us-overlay--modal
state.description: Overlay appears as a modal window

blocks.name: Tabs
blocks.description: These are the basic tabs used for landing pages. You can either reference a data-target for the urls or href for the target tabs. They have a non-js fallback and fold over to accordion when in small tablet view. They are initialised on page load if the tabs classes exist. To initialise call var tabs = new Tabs()

markup.example:
Tab 1 Tab 2 Tab 3

Test 1

Fatback capicola leberkas pork loin pork jowl. Meatloaf shoulder pancetta, salami prosciutto ribeye andouille chuck landjaeger short loin filet mignon sirloin. Pork chop tri-tip ham pork hamburger frankfurter leberkas short ribs biltong. Prosciutto ham hock rump, andouille tongue flank sirloin tri-tip ball tip frankfurter ham drumstick meatloaf pork loin.

Test 2

Kielbasa tenderloin spare ribs, andouille doner brisket chuck drumstick bresaola short loin pork t-bone ground round jowl. Ball tip pork loin doner tongue filet mignon biltong hamburger leberkas. Filet mignon kielbasa kevin short ribs, drumstick chuck shankle spare ribs tri-tip.

Test 3

Pig pastrami pork loin kielbasa, filet mignon meatloaf short ribs tenderloin. Pork loin leberkas kevin fatback porchetta bresaola. Cow rump shoulder pastrami. Andouille pork belly t-bone short ribs brisket. Bresaola pork belly tail salami capicola meatball. Pork belly beef ham landjaeger.

blocks.name: Breadcrumbs
blocks.description: Breadcrumbs are used to provide signposting of a users location and to enable quick navigation around the site. They are only to be used as a secondary means of navigation however. Pages should also be navigable through other means.

markup.example:
• uSwitch.com
  • Credit report
  • Credit reports guides
  • Statutory credit reports

blocks.name: Buttons
blocks.description: The default .us-btn button. There is a larger version of the button as well. Each of these styles adheres to the uSwitch branding colours. Currently we support anchor tags and button tags as the main ussage

markup.example: Link Button
Link Button
Link Button

state.name: .us-btn--hero
state.description: Navy outline used for buttons on hero banners

markup.example: Link Button
Link Button

state.name: .us-btn--arrowed , .us-btn--arrowed-right
state.description: Arrowed button used for CTAs (right pointing)

markup.example: Link Button

state.name: .us-btn--arrowed-left
state.description: Left pointing variation of arrowed buttons

markup.example: Link Button
Link Button
Link Button
Link Button
Link Button
Link Button

state.name: .us-btn--disabled
state.description: Disabled styling (can also be styled with :disabled)

markup.example: Link Button

markup.escaped:
<a href="#" class="us-btn">Link Button</a>
  <button class="us-btn">Button Element</button>

blocks.name: Content group
blocks.description: The .us-content-group is a separator element for content groupings. Ideal to split up landing pages with reasonable padding

state.name: .mobile-bordered
state.description: Adds a smaller border and padding to mobile devices. By default there is none

markup.example:
Swat at dog intrigued by the shower missing until dinner time and run in circles use lap as chair.

Swat at dog stretch and stand in front of the computer screen.

Swat at dog intrigued by the shower missing until dinner time and run in circles use lap as chair.

Swat at dog stretch and stand in front of the computer screen.

blocks.name: CTAs
blocks.description: Used within guide and news articles, these CTAs are intended to not interupt the content but to integrate in more subtle means.

markup.example:
It’s your report

Join the campaign to fight for free annual credit reports for everyone

Sign the petition

blocks.name: Guide article
blocks.description: This is the default guide item for uSwitch landing page. It extends the news item heavily.

markup.example:
Car insurance guides

Read our car insurance advice guides for the facts on why you need car insurance, the types of cover available, and tips on how to make a claim.

Read more

blocks.name: Hero
blocks.description: The .us-hero is used for the upper part of most pages. The hero can also be used mid-page to highlight other sections. We define it with .us-hero

markup.example:
Hero title

Swat at dog intrigued by the shower missing until dinner time.

blocks.name: Anchor links
blocks.description: Anchor tag styling, with and without a border

state.name: .us-link
state.description: Adds a border bottom to the link

state.name: .us-link--light
state.description: Changes the link colors to white for when links are placed on dark backgrounds

markup.escaped: <a href="#">Link</a>

blocks.name: Numbered/tick lists
blocks.description: A simple way of quickly styling up <ul> or <ol> with ticks or custom numbers - .us-ticked-list or .us-numbered-list, with options for a white or hero-blue background (by wrapping in .us-hero or .us-custom-list-alt)

markup.example:
• Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nunc sollicitudin iaculis bibendum.
  • Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nunc sollicitudin iaculis bibendum.

blocks.name: Link lists
blocks.description: The default .us-list list styling for any components with anchors in them. Used primarily to direct users to additional pages.

markup.example:
• List item 1
  • List item 2
  • List item 3

blocks.name: Loader
blocks.description: It shows when added the class .us-loader--loading and it can center itself on the parent container if you add .us-loader--centered

markup.example:
Loading deals
  • List item 1
  • List item 2
  • List item 3
  • List item 4

blocks.name: News article
blocks.description: The news item article standard. Built with .us-news-item. The news item image is a background image as the problem of not displaying <img> tags on mobile hasn't been resolved.

markup.example:
Consumer rights 14 Nov 2014

Customer uses promoted tweet to complain about BA

Sign of things to come? Social media helps to empower disgruntled consumer amid lost luggage row

More consumer rights

blocks.name: USPs
blocks.description: USPs (Unique Selling Points) are used within tables and on splash pages to highlight offers within a deal, and also to differentiate deals. General guidelines; There should only be one USP per deal. Text within USPs should be written in sentence case (not uppercase).

markup.example:
Shortened USP
Annotated USP
More information about USP goes here

Shortened USP
Annotated USP
More information about USP goes here

Shortened USP
Annotated USP

Annotated USP
More information about USP goes here

state.description: Micro persuasions eg. most popular, half price

state.name: .us-field-required
state.description: Any required form field has this class to show an asterisk beside the label

blocks.name: Icon inputs
blocks.description: In addition to our basic inputs we've got some useful input backgrounds that are used across the site. Each input background is a base64 encoded (for IE9 purposes) SVG to allow scalability on retina devices. Any browser not supporting SVG has a PNG fallback.

state.name: .postcode
state.description: Used for form fields asking for a postcode (typically in hero's)

state.name: .phone
state.description: Used when asking for a phone number

state.name: .pound
state.description: Used when asking for cost of something

markup.escaped: <input class='us-form-input' type='text'>

blocks.name: Inputs
blocks.description: The standard form input, .us-form-input, styled with our brand colours. Explicitly classed to allow individual app styling for other inputs

markup.escaped: <input class='us-form-input' type='text'>

blocks.name: Radios and checkboxes
blocks.description: Our standard radio and checkbox styling. Webkit/Blink browsers display our font icon tick or a box shadow circle. Other browsers fallback to default styling.

blocks.name: Selects
blocks.description: The .us-form-select is built with inline background-image SVGs for Webkit/Blink browsers that allow for Sass variable changes on the hover/normal colours. Firefox allows for .us-form-select wrap to be added on top of the select to replicate styling, whilst other browser fallback to native implementation. $select-base-color, $select-hover-color and $select-active-color allow for different colouring of the border/dropdown.

blocks.name: Form validation
blocks.description: Validation message and input styling provides a consistent look and feel to uStyle forms.

state.name: .us-validation--bordered
state.description: use this for any singular field validation or validation on backgrounds

markup.example: Validation message here
Validation message here

state.name: .us-validation--error
state.description: Error styling (default) for incorrect data on forms

markup.example: Validation message here
Validation message here

blocks.name: Icons
blocks.description: Icons are created by chaining classes together with us-icon. There are 3 sizes, 16px, 32px, 64px, these are named us-icon--small, us-icon--medium and us-icon--large respectively. There are 5 colours for each icon, white, typegrey, inputgrey, typecyan and custom. Where custom can differ depending on what the icon represents (for logos, the custom tends to be the brand colour of that company). If you want an icon to be part of a :pseudo element (:before, :after) then suffix your icon name with --before and --after respectively. To have an icon standalone with text as fallback, add us-icon--notext to the element.

markup.escaped: <div class="us-icon us-icon--medium us-icon--custom us-icon--hover-typecyan"></div>

blocks.name: Images
blocks.description: Helpful image classes for making images full width or floating within content.

blocks.name: Responsive
blocks.description: Utility classes to allow display of elements across devices. You have the option of displaying them as block, inline-block or inline elements. You can also hide elements by .us-{DEVICE}--hidden and will hide those elements above that breakpoint.

markup.example:
Shows large desktop and above
Shows desktop and above
Shows tablet and above
Shows small tablet and above
Shows mobile and above
Hides from tablet and above
